newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria's airline to return three leased planes.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria's airline to return three leased planes.

text.p: Bulgaria's troubled national carrier Balkan Airlines, hit by heavy losses in recent years, will return its three leased Airbus A320s planes, a Bulgarian official said on Tuesday.

"Balkan returns two Airbus A320s planes very soon and the third one will be returned later this year after its contract with a Turkish airline expires," a transport ministry official, who declined to be named, told Reuters.
Balkan had leased four Airbus A320s from the Japenese Orix Corp but returned one of them a year ago. Two A320 planes were detained in London and Amsterdam for unpaid fees last December.
The state-run airline also leased two Boeing 767-200s from Air France and three Boeing 737-500s from Australia's Ansett between 1990 and 1992 to upgrade its aging fleet.

The transport ministry said the leasing contracts were "shameful" and slammed the national carrier's mismanagement which had contributed to losses of five billion levs since the contracts were signed.
Debt-ridden Balkan increased its losses in the first half of 1996 by 510 million levs against the same period last year.
British consultancy firm KPMG will help Balkan Airline to work out a programme aimed at stabilising its finances and it is expected to be ready by October 30.
Bulgaria began procedures to privatise the national carrier in 1992 but in January 1995 the Privatisation Agency suspended them, citing a lack of buyers.
